Yeah, I don't get it.
Everyone is entitled to their opinions-
But how can people who've seen the first two seasons of this show honestly still love the show after what it has now become? Arrow used to be an amazing dark/gritty show about a vigilante with awesome action scenes and a plot that made sense. It wasn't perfect. But it was just so good. How can they think these new episodes are "amazing" or "the best episode ever?"
I mean seriously. They fired one arrow... in a show called Arrow about a super hero named the Green Arrow and Team Arrow....
Felicity/Ollicity is hamfisted and shoehorned into so many scenes. She saved the day "again, for the second time." Is there anything she can't do? The Arrow is now "Felicity and Friends"
The writing feels lazy and hard to follow. Now we have organic corhn and organic shipping ferhns. I still don't understand the main villain's motivations this season other than "I am le evil, humanity needs a reset". It just feels like it was all thrown together last minute.
There was always some relationship drama but it wasn't the main focus. It was tolerable because the show had an engaging plot and awesome action scenes.
If it had always been written this way, then maybe I would understand those types of comments but it was just sooo much better before.

My prediction. Honestly with the shitty writing lately I wouldn't be surprised at all if Dahmiehn Dahrhrk actually resurrects him. Then after they kill off dark in the season finale, it turns out Andy was being mind controlled the whole time. And he really is a "good guy" afterall. Oh and Felicity convinces Diggle not to kill him again just for the icing on the cake

It's like you don't understand how taxes work or what they are for like at all... You say that taxation is theft. and that governments are trying to steal our money. ..
If you want to argue about how much we are taxed, or how much say in how our tax dollars are spent, or for more transparency/accountability in where our tax dollars are spent, then I think you can make valid arguments. But it is absolutely idiotic to say that there should be no taxes or that taxation is stealing.
For example,
Do you like nature and or enjoy the outdoors?
* *No taxes would mean no state parks or public parks or playgrounds. No public bike paths or hiking trails.*
Do you enjoy traveling from one part of your city/state/territory/country to another?
* *No taxes would mean no public roads, no road repairs, and no public transportation.*
Do you think that everyone should have access to knowledge and opportunities to learn/receive and education?
* *No taxes would mean no public schools and no public libraries for people to learn*
Do you like to living in a safe place?
* *No taxes would mean no military or police to protect citizens from internal/external threats.*
How about if there is a fire?
* *No taxes means no firemen/firetrucks, etc.*
And so on... Point is, that our society simply would not work without taxes. (*And if want to argue for privatization of these industries, allow me to point out how well Comcast/time Warner handles the cable/internet industry as a counter example.*)
We absolutely need taxes. There are so many things that you use every single day that you don't even think about that are paid for by taxes. So taxes are definitely necessary, but taxes need to be fair and handled responsibly.
Everyone needs to pay their fair share. [And the rich should have to pay more taxes simply because they benefit more from the system.](http://www.zompist.com/richtax.htm) It's theft for the rich to avoid paying their fair share and yet still benefit fully from the system. The poor and middle classes are subsidizing the lifestyle of the ultra rich while they engage in "tax-dodging." We have every right to be outraged about this.
No one is holding the rich accountable. The government needs to do this and we the citizens need to make them do it. This is clearly not happening, as we are finding out again and again. Also, governments and elected representatives need to be transparent and accountable with regards to taxation. Citizens have a right to know how their taxes are spent. Citizens should have a say in what taxes are used for. Ideally we try to do this by electing officials that we feel best represent our interests. But it's time we had more say.

But it seems that all I ever encounter is either ignorance or a sort of defeatist apathy. Not desperation and outrage that might lead to some sort of change. None of my friends even know anything about the Panama Papers.

I disagree. The rest of us are basically subsidizing their lifestyle. They are getting all of the benefits of programs and infrastructure funded by taxes while contributing nothing to the system. And then we are left to cover their share as well.

I enjoyed this whole article and particularly these parts: Fitzgerald ... Let me tell you about the very rich. They are different from you and me. They possess and enjoy early, and it does something to them, makes them soft where we are hard, and cynical where we are trustful, in a way that, unless you were born rich, it is very difficult to understand. ***They think, deep in their hearts, that they are better than we are because we had to discover the compensations and refuges of life for ourselves.***
...
Perhaps the rich still believe they deserve to be rich, and too many of the non-rich believe it too. But their desperate attempts to hide their wealth beneath armies of lawyers and nests of imaginary companies and mailing addresses on distant islands suggest otherwise. *Theyre afraid that the illusion may be crumbling. Theyre afraid that one of these days well figure out how they got that money and decide to take it back.*
How do we take it back though?
